p: Welcome to the repository of favorite Fulton & Huffman family recipes!
If you're looking for something in particular, use the search box at the top right. And if you can't find it, !
If you're looking for inspiration on what to make, check out or .
A cake donut recipe that's simple to make and lightly spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg.
Mix the dry ingredients in a bowl.
Add melted butter and mix until crumbly.
Stir in the milk and egg until smooth. Knead lightly.
Roll to ¼ inch thickness on a floured surface and cut out donuts.
Fry in hot oil (375 degrees) until golden brown (about 3 minutes, flipping once).
Coat with cinnamon sugar or powdered sugar glaze or serve with raspberry jam.
Traditional Huffman family breakfast on Christmas Day.
Unroll 1 can of crescent roll dough and press it into the bottom of the pan.
Bake at 350° for 10 minutes, until the crust is lightly golden.
Combine the cream cheese, vanilla, egg white, and powdered sugar and mix until creamy.
Spread the mix in the pan.
Unroll the 2nd can of crescent roll dough and cover the mix/cherries.
Bake at 350° for 25-30 minutes, until crust is golden brown (you may need to rotate the pan).
Combine ¾ cup powdered sugar, milk, and vanilla in a bowl and mix until smooth.
Drizzle the glaze over the danish.
Chocolate chips and cocoa powder give this soft chocolate banana bread a deep chocolate flavor.
1 tsp salt (less if using salted butter)
Combine the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt in a bowl.
In another bowl, mash the bananas and mix in oil and butter.
Stir sugar, egg, and vanilla into the banana mix.
Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Don't overmix.
Stir in 1+ cup of chocolate chips.
Pour the batter into the prepared pans.
Sprinkle the remaining chocolate chips over the top.
Bake at 350° for 40-45 minutes, until a toothpick comes out clean.
Cool for 15 minutes before removing the bread from the pans.
Traditional Fulton family birthday breakfast. Soft, flakey pastry with almond and cherry flavor.
Mix ingredients like a pie crust.
Pat into two strips on a cookie sheet.
In a pot on the stove, heat water and butter to boiling.
Add flour and cook until the filling stirs into a ball.
Add eggs one at a time, beating well each time.
Spread the filling over the crust.
Cool before adding glaze and toppings.
Combine the powdered sugar, butter, and almond extract.
Add milk until the glaze reaches a spreading consistency.
Spread the glaze over the crust and filling.
Chop the cherries into small chunks.
Sprinkle toasted almonds and cherries on the kringlas.
This is a very popular Christmas snacking dish in the Huffman family. It's a great way to balance out all those sugary Christmas cookies!
1 can rotel (diced tomatoes and green chilis)
Combine the refried beans and taco seasoning and spread the mixture evenly across the bottom of a 9x13 serving dish.
Make guacamole with the avocados and guacamole mix and spread on top of the bean mixture.
Layer remaining ingredients in the order listed.
Simple, quick to prepare, and yummy!
Bring a large pot of water to boil, generously seasoned with salt, over high heat.
Cook the spaghetti according to package instructions, until just shy of al dente.
While the pasta is cooking, prepare the sauce by combining the olive oil, garlic, red pepper flakes and a pinch of salt in a large skillet.
Bring to the stove, over medium low heat, and cook slowly, letting the oil absorb the flavors from the garlic and pepper flakes.
When the pasta is almost al dente, transfer it to the skillet with the flavored oil along with ½ cup of the pasta water.
Turn the heat back to medium high and cook, stirring and tossing rapidly until the pasta is al dente and the sauce has thickened/emulsified and coats the pasta.
Remove from heat, add the chopped parsley, and serve with grated parmesan cheese on the side.
6 oz uncooked pasta (eg, egg tagliolini, bucatini, or spaghetti)
¾ cup finely grated grana padano or parmesan
Bring a large pot of water to boil, generously seasoned with salt, over high heat.
Cook the pasta according to package instructions, until about 2 minutes before tender.
While the pasta is cooking, melt 2 tbsp of butter in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the pepper and cook, swirling the pan, until toasted, about 1 minute.
Drain the pasta, reserving ¾ cup of the pasta water.
Add ½ cup of the pasta water to the skillet and bring it to a simmer.
Add the pasta and the remaining butter. Reduce heat to low.
Add the grana padano, stirring and tossing with tongs until melted. Remove the pan from the heat.
Add the pecorino, stirring and tossing until cheese melts, sauce coats the pasta, and pasta is al dente.
Add more pasta water if sauce seems dry.
The classiest chicken salad you've ever had.
1-2 green onions (green and white parts), sliced
Extremely yummy and healthy vegetarian tortilla soup.
1 can black beans, drained (or about 1.5 cups cooked black beans)
1 package soy curls (or about 2 cups of beans, tempeh, or your favorite protein here)
Optional: ¼ cup chopped cilantro (if you hate cilantro just leave it out, don't add parsley)
Optional: 2 teaspoons ground chipotle powder (or 1 chipotle pepper in adobo sauce chopped fine)
tortilla chips (or homemade baked/fried strips of corn tortillas)
Throw everything into the slow cooker and stir it up.
Cook on low for 6-8 hours. It's not a big deal if its more like 8-9, you just may want to add a tiny bit of water at the end.
Serve with a squeeze of lime juice, chopped green onion, cilantro, cut up avocado, crushed tortilla chips, extra salsa and, sliced black olives.
Lentils and hot dogs. It says "for children", but it's really for all ages.
1 cup white or red wine (or meat broth)
Rinse the lentils, peel and slice the carrots, and chop the onion.
Put the lentils, chopped carrots, and chopped onion in a large saucepan.
Add thyme (to taste/smell) and the bay leaf.
Cover with water, bring it to a boil, and simmer on low heat for 1 hour.
Add the oil to a frying pan and cook the bacon, hot dogs, and garlic.
Add the tomato paste and white wine.
Cook on low heat for 10 minutes, then add the lentil mixture.
Mix gently, adding water if needed.
A fun, fresh take on baked salmon. The maple syrup and soy sauce play off each other well.
Place salmon fillets in a foil-lined pan.
Whisk together maple syrup, soy sauce, sesame oil, and minced garlic.
Pour 75% of the glaze over the salmon.
Bake at 375° for ~ 30 minutes (20+ minutes per inch of thickness).
Pour the remaining glaze into a small pan and simmer it for ~ 5 minutes until it thickens.
Pour the glaze over the baked salmon and garnish with sesame seeds.
Cut the corn off the cobs.
Prepare the rice in a rice cooker, adding ¼ cup extra water and the corn cobs.
Remove the corn cobs 5 minutes before the rice has finished cooking and add the corn kernels.
Zest and juice the lemon and add to the rice.
Add the butter and salt to taste.
Zest and juice the lemon and add to the sour cream. Add salt to taste.
Lightly whisk the egg in a large bowl.
Add 2 tbsp of the lemony sour cream sauce.
Add the remaining ingredients. Mix by hand.
Form into balls 1-1½ inches in diameter.
Place on a lined baking sheet and bake at 425°F for 10 minutes, until cooked through.
Top the corn butter rice with the meatballs, lemony sour cream, cucumber, and cilantro.
Prepare rice in a rice cooker.
Slice the sausages and fry them in a wok with the olive and chili oil.
Drain the beans and add them to the wok.
Toss the mixture thoroughly, until the beans are heated through.
Add the rice to the wok and toss until it is evenly distributed.
Add the creole seasoning to taste.
Serve with a dollop of sour cream.
Huffman Thanksgiving favorite. The cranberry balances the apples.
Mix filling ingredients and place in 2 quart casserole dish (9x13 dish).
Mix topping and pour over filling.
Preheat oven to 425°. Scrub the potatoes, prick them with a fork, and place them in a foil-lined baking pan.

Slice the full head of garlic along its equator, and place both halves face down on a separate piece of foil. Drizzle the garlic with olive oil, and season with salt and pepper. Fold the edges of the foil up around the garlic and crimp it closed. Place the foil pouch in the baking pan.
Bake the potatoes and garlic for 65-75 minutes, until a knife slices through the potatoes easily. Let the potatoes cool slightly.
Optionally halve the potatoes lengthwise and remove the skins. Place the potatoes in a mixer. Squeeze the garlic clovess out of their shells and into the mixer as well.
Add butter and mix until there are only a few lumps. Add milk until the potatoes are creamy. Add salt and pepper to taste.
Chop chives and serve alongside the potatoes.
The only way to eat butternut squash.
Peel the squash, slice it in two, and remove the seeds. Dice the squash flesh into ~½ inch cubes.
Mix all ingredients together until the squash chunks are well coated.
Spread the chunks out on a baking pan, and roast for 35 minutes, until the squash is tender.

Peel sweet potatoes, chop into 1-inch cubes, and simmer until soft (~ 15-20 minutes). (Alternatively, bake whole sweet potatoes at 425° for ~ 1 hour. Less water added makes for a more intense sweet potato flavor.)
Drain the sweet potatoes and mash them.
Mix the filling ingredients into the sweet potatoes, put in the baking dish.
Combine the topping ingredients and mix until it clumps together. Put on top of the filling.
Bake until mostly set in the middle and golden on top (~ 25-30 minutes). Serve hot/warm.
Decadent but healthy; you'll be left wanting more.
1 medium apple (preferably tart; eg, Granny Smith)
1½ tbsp apple cider vinegar (or red wine)
Pull the kale leaves off from the tough stems and discard the stems. Chop the kale into small, bite-sized pieces, and put it in a big salad bowl.
Sprinkle a small pinch of sea salt over the kale and massage the leaves with your hands by lightly scrunching big handfuls at a time, until the leaves are darker in color and fragrant.
Coarsely chop the pecans and cranberries (or cherries) and add them to the bowl. Chop the apple into small, bite-sized pieces and add it to the bowl as well. Crumble the goat cheese over the top.

In a small bowl, whisk the dressing ingredients together and pour the dressing over the salad. Toss until the salad is evenly coated with dressing. Serve immediately, or for even better flavor, let the salad marinate in the dressing for 10 to 20 minutes beforehand.
12-18 chopped apples (size-dependent), enough to fill a 9x13 dish mostly full
½ tsp salt (more if using unsalted butter)
Combine the filling ingredients (ensure apples are evenly coated) and pour the mixture into the 9x13 pan.
Combine the topping ingredients, adding the butter last.
Stir the topping until crumbly and spread it over the filling.
Bake at 350° for 45-60 minutes, until topping looks golden brown.
Also known as peanut butter balls. The perfect Christmas sweet.
Combine peanut butter, butter, and vanilla in a mixer until creamy.
Add powdered sugar 1 cup at a time. Final dough should be thick and slightly crumbly.
Pat/combine by hand into a large ball.
Roll into slightly larger than marble-sized balls and place on wax paper.
Cover in cling wrap and refrigerate for at least one hour.
Melt chocolate chips (using microwave, double boiler, chocolate melter, etc.).
Use toothpicks to dip the chilled balls in the melted chocolate and place them on wax paper.
Also called baby shower cake by the Fulton family. Sweet, buttery, and nutty.
Grease and flour two 9-inch round baking pans.
Cream the butter and sugar. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Slowly add the dry ingredients to the creamed mixture, alternating with milk.
Stir in the vanilla and pecans.
Pour the batter into the pans and bake at 350° for 25-30 minutes.
Cool for 10 minutes before removing the cakes from the pans, then let the cakes cool completely.
Add the vanilla and almond extracts.
Add milk until the frosting is smooth.
Ben's favorite cake. He designed it by merging several recipes together for his birthday in 2019.
½ to ¾ stick unsalted butter, softened
Grease and flour a 9x13 pan (or two 9-inch round pans).
Beat together the eggs, oil, applesauce, sugars, and vanilla.
Mix in the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg.
Stir in the crushed pineapple, carrots, and pecans.
Bake at 350° for 40-50 minutes, until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool for 10 minutes before removing the cakes from the pans, then let the cakes cool completely.
Combine the butter, cream cheese, powdered sugar, and vanilla. Beat until smooth and creamy.
Fulton family's traditional cookie recipe, as listed on the side of the Toll House Chocolate Chips tin.
1 tsp salt (more if butter was unsalted)
Cream the butter, sugars, and vanilla. Beat in the eggs.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the flour mixture to the creamed mixture.
Cool the dough in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Scoop rounded spoonfuls of the dough onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
Broil the cookies for for 2-3 minutes, until the tops are golden.
Set the oven to 375° and bake the cookies for 6-8 minutes. Do not overbake.
½ cup firmly packed light brown sugar
Cream the butter, peanut butter, and sugars until fluffy and smooth, about 4 to 6 minutes.
Add the egg and vanilla and continue beating until smooth.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Reduce mixer speed to low and gradually incorporate the dry flour mixture.
Fold in the chocolate, rice krispies, oats, and yellow raisins. Do not overmix.
Use a 1 tbsp scoop to drop the dough 2 in apart on a lined baking sheet.
Bake at 375° for 8 to 10 minutes, or until the edges have lightly browned but the tops are still very blonde.
Soft and gingery cookies that don't dry out.
Beat butter on medium speed until completely smooth (~ 1 minute).
Add brown sugar and molasses and beat on medium speed until creamy, scraping sides of bowl.
Beat in egg and vanilla at high speed for 2 minutes.
In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, ginger, cinnamon, allspice, and cloves.
Mix dry ingredients into wet ingredients at a low speed. Dough should be thick and sticky.
Divide dough in half, pat both halves into rough disc shapes, wrap them tightly in plastic wrap, and store them overnight in the fridge.
Roll out discs until they're ¼ inch thick, using flour as needed.
Use cookie cutters, place cookies on baking sheets lined with baking parchment.
Bake cookies for 9-10 minutes, rotating as needed. Do not overbake.
This Huffman favorite brings butterscotch to Christmas.
½ cup white chocolate chips or butterscotch chips
Grease a 9x13 pan. Line it with parchment paper and leave an overhang on the sides.
In a large bowl, combine the graham cracker crumbs and melted butter until the crumbs are evenly moistened.
Press the wet cracker crumbs into the bottom of the greased baking dish.
Bake at 325° for 8-10 minutes until lightly brown.
Sprinkle the semi-sweet chocolate chips, walnuts, coconut, and white chocolate chips over the hot crust. Use a spatula to spread it out and cover the crust evenly.
Pour the sweetened condensed milk over the top but do not stir.
Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until lightly browned and the coconut flakes are golden.
Let it cool to room temperature. Using the overhangs, lift the baked dish onto a flat surface.
Cut into bars with a sharp knife.
All-time favorite Fulton Christmas cookie. Also called snowballs or Mexican wedding cookies.
4 sticks butter, straight from the fridge
Cut the butter into the flour using your hands.
Roll the dough into balls the size of marbles. Smaller is better.
Bake at 325° for 30 minutes, until just blushed. Do not overbake; they should not be golden.
Let cool slightly, then roll them in powdered sugar.
Let cool completely, then roll them in powdered sugar again.
Peanut butter. What more is there to say?
½ tsp salt (more if butter was unsalted)
1 cup chopped peanuts (less if chunky peanut butter)
Cream butter, peanut butter, and sugars.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda.
Gradually add the flour mixture to the creamed mixture.
Cool the dough in fridge for 30-60 minutes.
Roll the dough into 1 inch balls and criss-cross with fork.
Bake at 375° for 10 minutes, until edges begin to brown.
They melt in your mouth. First served by Noelle at Christmas 2018.
In large mixing bowl, beat the cream cheese and extract until smooth.
Gradually add confectioners’ sugar, one cup at a time, beating well (the dough will be very stiff... you may find that you don’t need all 9 cups).
Shape into 1 inch balls and flatten into patties. Place on waxed paper; layer patties and waxed paper.
Refrigerate for one hour or until chilled.

In microwave, melt chips and shortening; stir until smooth. This can be a little tricky... melt for 1 minute intervals, stirring after each until chocolate is smooth; stirring helps to melt chips and will prevent from overheating. Cool slightly.
Use a fork to dip the patties in melted chocolate and place on waxed paper.
Let the patties harden completely before layering them in a container. Store in the fridge.
A tasty treat first introduced by Andrea Fischer.
1 frozen store-bought pie crust in a pie plate
Pre-bake the crust per the instructions on the box.
In a small bowl, whisk together the egg, lemon juice, and salt.
Use a pastry brush to coat the bottom and sides of the pie crust with a thin layer of egg wash.
Bake, uncovered, for an additional 5 minutes.
Slice the rhubarb into ½-inch chunks.
Place the rhubarb in a bowl and toss it in ¼ cup of sugar.
Whisk together the remaining 1¼ cup sugar, flour, eggs, butter, cream, and lemon juice until combined.
Pour the filling into the prepared crust and scatter the rhubarb evenly on top, discarding any liquid at the bottom of the bowl.
Bake the pie at 350° for 60 to 65 minutes, or until the edges of the filling are set but the center still wobbles slightly.
Cool the pie on a wire rack for at least 2 hours before serving.
Oldie but a goodie, and relatively unique as cookies go. Fulton/Wright family favorite going back to the mid-1900s.
Combine all ingredients but the pecans.
Roll the dough into balls by the teaspoonful.
Flatten the balls with the bottom of a floured cup.
Press a pecan into the center of each cookie.
Bake at 300° for 25-30 minutes, until the cookies are golden brown around the edges.
Smooth and creamy cookies. White chocolate brings the decadence and almond brings the class.
½ tsp salt (more if butter was unsalted)
Cream the butter, sugars, almond, and vanilla.
In a separate bowl, combine the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the flour mixture to the creamed mixture.
Cool the dough in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Scoop rounded spoonfuls of the dough onto an ungreased cookie sheet.
Broil the cookies for for 2-3 minutes, until the tops are golden.
Set the oven to 350° and bake the cookies for 7-9 minutes, until edges are golden brown.
The perfect drink for a cold night!
Add all ingredients to a slow cooker. Stir in the sugar.
Set slow cooker to high temperature until the mixture boils. Remove the cloves and cinnamon, and set the cooker to low temperature.
